newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Yugo/London Club deal possible without IMF-Tanjug.
newsitem.headline: Yugo/London Club deal possible without IMF-Tanjug.

text.p: A deal between Yugoslavia and the London club of creditors is possible even without Belgrade regulating its status in the IMF first, the Tanjug news agency quoted a government official as saying on Friday.
The London club is expected to discuss a draft deal with Yugoslavia by the end of November, the Yugoslav chief negotiator and federal minister without portfolio, Vuk Ognjanovic told Tanjug.

"Along with our readiness to pay back debts, we now want new cooperation with memebers of the international banking community," Ognjanovic said, adding such a proposal would be in the form of a job offer to the banks.
Such an offer is in Yugoslavia's interest and will allow the country to create opportunities to service its foreign debt, the minister said.
According to Ognjanovic, Yugoslavia offered the London club a partial debt-for-equity swap.

He argued that once they are shareholders in Yugoslav companies, foreign creditors would naturally do everything to kick-start production and create opportunities for Yugoslavia to pay off its foreign debt.
Another chunk of the debt, not included in the debt-for- equity swap, would need to be reorganised, he said.
"We do not ask for debt write-off but for a realistic reduction of the debt," Ognjanovic was quoted as saying.
The minister argued there was a need to review the way the interest rate is calculated.
He said Yugoslavia will also seek a grace period in servicing its debt, to provide breathing-space to give the country time to revive its economy and begin to service its debt.
Ognjanovic told Tanjug he hoped that in the meantime talks between Yugoslavia and the London club will resume.

The minister was not immediately available to confirm Tanjug's report, but a source close to the finance ministry told Reuters that the Yugoslav government offered to meet the London club creditors later this month in Belgrade.

"Those would be technical talks again, and an opportunity to present our fiscal, financial and development capacities and plans," the source said. -- Gordana Filipovic, Belgrade newsroom, +381 11 222 4254
